results.title: Take the cue train
results.creator_credit: Brian Bergin, Lesley Hammond and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This film makes the point that training can help at all levels from grass roots to executive and that most of it can be done on the job. Examples from large and small industries, manufacturing and service industries emphasise the benefits of staff training.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Bergin, Lesley Hammond and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: A Study in choreography for camera
results.brief_description: This is the third film of the prominent American experimental film-maker, Maya Deren. It elaborates a technique developed in her previous film ‘At Land’ in which fresh contiguities of shot relations were achieved through the device of photographing a movement begun in one place, and concluding it by photographing the completion of the movement in another place, thus creating a cinematic time and place which enabled unrelated persons, place and objects to be related and brought into harmony, resulting in a new complexity of meaning and form. ‘A Study in Choreography for Camera’ features a leap by the dancer Talley Beatty, in which he begins his leap in the woods, continues it against the background of the Metropolitan Museum’s Egyptian Hall, and finishes it on the cliffs overlooking a river. Slow motion is used to prolong and dramatise the movement. John Martin, dance critic of the ‘New York Times’ called this film “virtually the beginnings of a new art, choreocinema, in which the dancer and the camera collaborate on the creation of a single new work of art.”

results.title: Stirring the pool
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Wayne Le Clos, Gil Brealey, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Commonwealth Public Service Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel or People”.
A new typist is asked to do a job for the manager instead of the senior typist, who is not present. Afterwards the senior typist voices her resentment, causing the new girl to feel unhappy. Another typist informs the new typist that the attitude of the senior typist is not new and has caused many resignations. What is the answer to internal warfare in the typing pool? Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Station 307
results.creator_credit: Louis Malle, Jacques-Yves Cousteau and British Petroleum
results.brief_description: Completely new techniques in the search for oil. The research vessel “Calypso”, equipped with special scientific gear, took a team of geologists and aqualung divers to survey the sea bed of the Persian Gulf in 1954. A submarine gravimeter is seen in action on the sea bed, and the divers, filmed at depths up to 100 feet, are shown taking samples from the floor of the Gulf. The samples are studied by geologists while the “Calypso” moves on to a new station.

results.title: Spring fever
results.brief_description: Introduced by scenes at Flemington in the 1860’s, preparations for the Melbourne Cup are shown, social sidelights and finally the running of the Centenary Melbourne Cup on 1st. November, 1960.

results.title: The Spongers
results.creator_credit: Roland Joffe, Tony Garnett and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A play written by Jim Allen and set during the 1977 Silver Jubilee. Britain seems to be in a state of rejoicing, and there seems to be plenty of money to spend on the festivities, but Pauline has nothing to cheer about. She has four children, the eldest is a Downs Syndrome child, she has no income and because of the family cannot go out to work. In theory the social service exists to help those in such situations. In practice there are tribunals, councils and welfare departments to be faced.

results.title: The Spanish earth
results.creator_credit: Joris Ivens and Contemporary Historians Production
results.brief_description: Made largely in the village of Fuentaduena, 40 miles from Madrid on the Valencia road, in the front lines and in Madrid itself. The story centres around the necessity for keeping the road to Madrid open, and the life of the villagers of Fuentaduena who were working against time and in spite of bombing from the air, to complete and irrigation channel which would bring water to their fields and enable them to grow food for the besieged city of Madrid. Commentary and narration by Ernest Hemmingway; photography by John Ferno and Joris Ivens; editing by Helen van Donen; musical arrangement from Spanish folk tunes by Marc Blitzstein and Virgil Thomson; production committee - Archibald MacLeish, Lillian Hellman and John dos Passos.

results.title: So this Is Jollygood
results.creator_credit: Tex Ringworm, Sir Michael Balcon and W&F Film Service Ltd
results.brief_description: During one of the periodic slumps in the British Film Industry, Adrian Brunel produced several satires on “film” types. This one describes the trials of a film producer, the hunt for a financier, shows some of the “technicians” and actors (such as the great Rhubarb Vaselino), and concludes with an excerpt from the production of a harrowing drama. Other credits include: Camera artist - S.L.U. Lloyd, Electrical effects - John D’Arc, Scenario - Saimole Story.

results.title: Sentinels of silence
results.creator_credit: Robert Amram, Manuel Arango and Producciones Concord
results.brief_description: Depicts aspects of pre-Columbian monumental architecture in Mexico. Provides a basis for a subjective appreciation of early Mesoamerican cultures. Stimulates interest in early American civilisations. Encourages further study of pre-Columbian cultures. Narrated by Orson Welles. (Awards: Academy Award for Best Short Documentary; Academy Award for Best Live Action Short)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Amram, Manuel Arango and Producciones Concord

results.title: Sapphire
results.creator_credit: Basil Dearden, Basil Relph and Artna
results.brief_description: Investigation into the murder of a music student, Sapphire Robbins, leads the detectives along London’s coloured population. Although she passed for white, Sapphire was half Negro, and her dark-skinned brother is one of several suspects. When the detective expose, in all its irrationality, the violent hate that Sapphire managed to arouse, the murderer is driven into a confession. The extract is taken halfway through the film when the police investigation is underway and various people who have known Sapphire Robbins are being questioned. Det Hazard (Nigel Patrick), Det Learoyd (Michael Craig), David Farris (Paul Massie), Mildred Harris (Yvonne Mitchell), Mr Harris (Bernard Miles), Mrs Harris (Olga Lindo), Dr Robbins (Earl Cameron), Paul Slade (Gordon Heath).
